course_title: Learning, Using and Sharing Indigenous Languages

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate understanding of the diversity of Indigenous language learning contexts.
Understand the impacts of colonisation on Indigenous languages loss and the activism to maintain and revitalize them.
Articulate protocols, and ethical practices associated with teaching, learning and using Indigenous languages.

Effectively plan and develop a unit within a language program or a learning plan, tailored to the needs of diverse learners, incorporating best practices from First Nations language teaching methodologies and contemporary second language acquisition strategies.
Demonstrate high level communication skills including structuring and supporting an argument.

assessments.task_description:
In this assessment, you will work individually to develop a sequence of at least four language lessons or learning activities for a context that you choose.

For the Language Learning Plan, you will complete the following:

  1. Brief introduction including the context, aims and target learners for the sequence and their characteristics.
  2. Explanation of the teaching/learning approach underpinning the lessons, with reference to course materials, discussions and readings.
  3. A detailed description of each lesson.
  4. A discussion of resources (required and or/available) to support the learning plan.

 Expected length of the language learning plan is approximately 2000 words (+/- 10%, NO LONGER THAN 2200 words).

Statement on Generative AI & MT

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit via Turnitin. If you have more than one document created in the same program or format (Word, PDF), please create a single document to submit.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Rationale and Reflection - Language Learning Plan
assessments.task_description:
In this assessment, you will work individually to record a short video presentation where you discuss the rationale behind your Language Learning Plan developed for Assessment 1 and reflect on choices you made in developing the sequence of lessons or learning activities.

Maximum duration: 10 minutes.

In the presentation you should:

  • Introduce yourself
  • Give some background information on the language, including impacts of colonisation on numbers of speakers and efforts to revitalise the language
  • Describe the intended audience and purpose of the language learning sequence
  • Describe one of your learning activities or lessons.
  • Explain the teaching or learning approaches or methodologies it uses, with reference to course readings and materials
  • Explain the background knowledge of the learners and how the approach and content in the activity is suited to the learner
  • Describe how you will know whether learners have learnt what you intended?
  • Develop a critical reflection that evaluates the strengths and weaknesses of your language learning plan in meeting its intended purpose, including how it aligns with protocols or ethical practices.

You may use visual aids such as slides and images of your learning plan and resources to support the presentation.

If you consent, your presentation video will be shared with other students in this course for peer learning and discussion in an online session following the intensive.

Statement on Generative AI & MT

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support you in completing this assessment task. However, given this task is designed to be your rationale and reflection, AI is unlikely to be very useful. Nevertheless, you may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Please submit your video via the link to EchoVideo in the Assessment tab on Blackboard
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
In this assessment, you will work in a small group (2-4 students) to:

  • select two academic articles/book chapters/videos* on language teaching and/or learning methods
  • describe and evaluate the selected sources
  • compare and contrast selected sources.

*One source must be written unless negotiated with course coordinator.

Expected length of the review is approximately 1500 words (+/- 10%, NO LONGER THAN 1650 words).

Statement on Generative AI & MT

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit via Turnitin. Each group member will submit the same group review.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Language learning is an ongoing journey, and this course invites you to actively reflect on that process.

You are encouraged to incorporate ideas, strategies, and personal reflections into into 4 weekly entries in this journal.

The length guide per entry is 200 words (+/- 10%).

Your entry should include descriptions of:

  • the specific target language you have set for your learning in this period
  • language materials you accessed
  • language learning strategies you have tried

Reflect on your above descriptions to include:

  • new learnings about your language
  • reflections on your engagement with people or resources
  • helpful and unhelpful strategies or ideas
  • ideas for future language learning pathways
  • links between theory or readings and real-life situations

While you should engage with your journal regularly over designated four weeks of the course, please note that the journal will be assessed as a whole at the end of the course, using the marking rubric provided in Blackboard. Word limit for your journal submission is a total of 800 words +/- %10.

Statement on Generative AI & MT

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Enter 4 weekly entries in the journal tab in Ultra.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Intensive Day 1

Session 1

Diversity of Indigenous language learning contexts

Diversity of goals for Language learning and Language revitalisation

Impacts of colonisation on Indigenous languages

Session 2

How do we learn sounds?

  • stages of first language (L1) acquisition – how babies learn the sounds around them
  • differences between first language (L1) learning and second language (L2) learning
  • strategies for learners and 'unlearners' 

Session 3

  • Active language learning
  • What is the place of accent, fluency, proficiency, accreditation in Indigenous Language revitalisation?
  • Review of strategies for language learning
  • Setting goals for language learning
  • Assignment planning – Task 3 Journal
learning_activities.topic_description: Intensive Day 1 Session 1 Diversity of Indigenous language learning contexts Diversity of goals for Language learning and Language revitalisation Impacts of colonisation on Indigenous languages Session 2 How do we learn sounds? stages of first language (L1) acquisition – how babies learn the sounds around them differences between first language (L1) learning and second language (L2) learning strategies for learners and 'unlearners' Session 3 Active language learning What is the place of accent, fluency, proficiency, accreditation in Indigenous Language revitalisation? Review of strategies for language learning Setting goals for language learning Assignment planning – Task 3 Journal

learning_activities.topic:
Intensive Day 2

Session 1

  • How are languages learnt?
  • stages of first language (L1) acquisition – how babies learn the language/s around them
  • formulaic language – repeating familiar phrases correctly
  • ‘interlanguage’ or ‘learner language’
  • differences between first language (L1) learning and second language (L2) learning
  • Factors affecting second language (L2) acquisition (part 1)

Session 2

How are languages learnt?

Factors affecting second language (L2) acquisition (part 1)

  • Age
  • First language (L1) background (e.g. difficulties with sounds and sound combinations, transfer of meanings, difference or similarity of grammar)
  • Prior language experiences and explicit language learning
  • Prior literacy experiences (reading, writing, comprehension)

Session 3

  • Factors affecting second language (L2) acquisition (part 3)
  • Comprehensible input hypothesis
  • Sequencing language learning – an exemplar
  • Assignment planning - Task 1 Language learning plan

Learning outcomes: L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Intensive Day 2 Session 1 How are languages learnt? stages of first language (L1) acquisition – how babies learn the language/s around them formulaic language – repeating familiar phrases correctly ‘interlanguage’ or ‘learner language’ differences between first language (L1) learning and second language (L2) learning Factors affecting second language (L2) acquisition (part 1) Session 2 How are languages learnt? Factors affecting second language (L2) acquisition (part 1) Age First language (L1) background (e.g. difficulties with sounds and sound combinations, transfer of meanings, difference or similarity of grammar) Prior language experiences and explicit language learning Prior literacy experiences (reading, writing, comprehension) Session 3 Factors affecting second language (L2) acquisition (part 3) Comprehensible input hypothesis Sequencing language learning – an exemplar Assignment planning - Task 1 Language learning plan

learning_activities.topic:
Intensive Day 3

Session 1

Introduction to language teaching approaches through hands-on activities

  • Behaviourist: For beginner learners, some rote-learning is useful (learners tend to do this strategically in the early stages of acquisition anyway)
  • Structuralist: Explicitly teaching language structures (i.e, generalisations) at an appropriate level assists students’ acquisition of these structures 
  • Functional: Teaching situational language (i.e, language for specific purposes) is a useful way to target teaching and provide language that is useful for students
  • Interactive: Using language (if you have it) is fun – language has a fundamentally social function. Using and practising language is essential for developing fluency.
  • Language teaching approaches – Behaviourist
  • Rote learning, Drilling and repetition, Songs and rhymes
  • TPR – Total Physical Response, ASLA – Accelerated Second Language Acquisition
  • Opportunities for rote language learning through digital technologies

 Session 2 

Language teaching approaches – Structured/Explicit

  • Explicit grammar teaching
  • Translation activities
  • Fill-in-the-blanks
  • Error correction
  • Opportunities for structured/explicit language learning through digital technologies

Session 3 

Language teaching approaches – Functional

  • Task-based language for specific purposes, contexts and domains (Amery – the four Fs?)
  • Modelling and scaffolding
  • Role-play scenarios
  • Opportunities for functional language learning through digital technologies
  • Assignment planning – Task 1 & 4 

Learning outcomes: L02, L04

Using and practising language is essential for developing fluency. Modelling and scaffolding Role-play scenarios Opportunities for functional language learning through digital technologies Assignment planning – Task 1 & 4

learning_activities.topic:
Intensive Day 4

Session 1

Language teaching approaches – Interactive/Immersive

  • Implicit learning
  • Communication-centred
  • Group learning
  • Master-apprentice
  • ‘Immersion’ language learning in a language revitalisation context
  • Opportunities for interactive/immersive language learning through digital technologies

Session 2 

  • Age-appropriate pedagogies
  • Repurposing resources and activities across age groups

Session 3 

 Planning for Assessment – Task 4 Group reading review

learning_activities.topic:
Intensive Day 5

Session 1

Protocols and ethical practices associated with teaching and learning Indigenous languages

  • Indigenous Cultural and Intellectual Property (ICIP)
  • Involvement of Elders
  • Communication and agreements between language speakers/owners and education providers
  • Protocols and ethics of being on country

Bringing it together - Planning for language teaching and learning

  • Constraints of the teaching and learning environment
  • Resources available
  • How to plan a sequence of lessons that build on each other
  • How to give feedback to learners

Session 2

Bringing grammatical knowledge into language learning through plain language descriptions

  • Guest talk from Gari Tudor Smith

Session 3

Recap, review and assessments
